abstract: Google releases “eyes-free” applications that make the touch-screen T-Mobile G1 accessible to blind users, and more useful for others.
snippet: Google releases “eyes-free” applications that make the touch-screen T-Mobile G1 accessible to blind users, and more useful for others.
lead_paragraph: The featureless glassy screens of touch-screen phones may seem like a forbidding barrier for blind users, who often rely on tactile clues to feel their way around. But a pair of engineers at Google, T.V. Raman, who is blind, and Charles Chen, who is sighted, have developed software that makes the touch-screen T-Mobile G1, which uses Google’s Android software, more accessible to blind users. They hope the technology will also be useful to anyone who needs to operate a phone without looking at the screen, like drivers.

headline.main: Google’s Phone Apps for the Blind, and Everyone Else
